Sparse Recovery

Posted on 2021-03-31 Edited on 2021-04-08

Model

The focus of this article is recovering a sparse vector x∈Rnx \in \mathbb{R}^nx∈Rn in the streaming setting. Initially, x=0x = 0x=0. Then we see a sequence of updates (i,Δ)(i, \Delta)(i,Δ) each causing the change xi←xi+Δx_i \leftarrow x_i + \Deltaxi​←xi​+Δ. There are three popular studied models

  1. insertion only: Δ=1\Delta = 1Δ=1 for each update.
  2. strict turnstile: Δ\DeltaΔ can be negative, but it is guaranteed that x≥0x \ge 0x≥0 all the time.
  3. general turnstile: Δ\DeltaΔ can be negative, and entries of xxx can be negative.

Let supp(x)⊂[n]\text{supp}(x) \subset [n]supp(x)⊂[n] be the set of nonzero indices of xxx. The vector xxx is called kkk sparse if supp(x)≤k\text{supp}(x) \le ksupp(x)≤k.

Goal. Given an integer kkk, design a data structure such that, if xxx is kkk sparse, the structure returns xxx exactly; otherwise, the return can be arbitrary.

As we can’t actually store real numbers, we use the following assumption:

The updates are integers and the entries of xxx are bounded by ±M\pm M±M.

With this restriction, it suffices to solve this problem in a finite field Fp\mathbb{F}_pFp​ where p≥max⁡{n,M}p \ge \max \{ n, M \}p≥max{n,M}. As opposed to the naive solution that keeps all entries of xxx and uses O(nlog⁡M)O(n \log M)O(nlogM) bits of memory, we show that the memory can be reduced to O(klog⁡(nM))O( k \log (nM) )O(klog(nM)) bits.

Algorithm

The problem is easy to solve in the insertion only model. We can use a hash set that keeps the first kkk occurrence of the indices. If the we detect the k+1k + 1k+1 new index, we can just report error.

The scenario is a little more complicated for the other two models. E.g., let n=4n = 4n=4 and k=1k = 1k=1. Consider the following stream

(1,1),(2,1),(3,−1),(4,1),(1,−1),(2,−1),(3,1). (1, 1), (2, 1), (3, -1), (4, 1), (1, -1), (2, -1), (3, 1). (1,1),(2,1),(3,−1),(4,1),(1,−1),(2,−1),(3,1).

The vector xxx is finally 111-sparse and the only non-zero index is revealed at the end of the stream.

Solution 1

Encode

In the first approach, we use a matrix H∈Fpm×nH \in \mathbb{F}_p^{m \times n}H∈Fpm×n​ (mmm to be determined) and encode xxx as Enc(x)=Hx\mathbb{Enc}(x) = H xEnc(x)=Hx. If the following property holds, we are guaranteed to recover xxx if it is kkk sparse.

For every kkk sparse x,x′∈Fpnx, x' \in \mathbb{F}_p^nx,x′∈Fpn​, if x≠x′x \neq x'x=x′, then Hx≠Hx′Hx \neq H x'Hx=Hx′.

If Hx≠Hx′H x \neq Hx'Hx=Hx′, then H(x−x′)≠0H (x - x') \neq 0H(x−x′)=0. Observe that x−x′x - x'x−x′ is a 2k2k2k sparse vector. This is equivalent to that Hz≠0H z \neq 0Hz=0 for every nonzero 2k2k2k sparse vector z∈Fpnz \in \mathbb{F}_p^nz∈Fpn​.

Such HHH does exists, with m=2km = 2km=2k. Let a1,a2,...,an∈Fpa_1, a_2, ..., a_n \in \mathbb{F}_pa1​,a2​,...,an​∈Fp​ be different integers. Then HHH is given as

H=[11...1...1a1a2...ai...ana12a22...ai2...an2...a12k−1a22k−1...ai2k−1...an2k−1] H = \begin{bmatrix} 1 &1 &... &1 &... &1 \\ a_1 &a_2 &... &a_i &... &a_n \\ a_1^2 &a_2^2 &... &a_i^2 &... &a_n^2 \\ ...\\ a_1^{2k - 1} &a_2^{2k - 1} &... &a_i^{2k - 1} &... &a_n^{2k - 1} \end{bmatrix} H=⎣⎢⎢⎢⎢⎢⎡​1a1​a12​...a12k−1​​1a2​a22​a22k−1​​............​1ai​ai2​ai2k−1​​............​1an​an2​an2k−1​​⎦⎥⎥⎥⎥⎥⎤​

Let S=supp(z)⊂[n]S = \text{supp}(z) \subset [n]S=supp(z)⊂[n] be a set of size 2k2k2k. Denote zSz_SzS​ be the vector by keeping only the nonzero dimensions of zzz and HSH_SHS​ be an 2k×2k2k \times 2k2k×2k matrix by keeping only columns indexed by SSS. Then Hz=HSzSH z = H_S z_SHz=HS​zS​. We show that the rows of HSH_SHS​ are linearly independently, hence its columns. It follows that if zS≠0⟹HSzS≠0z_S \neq 0 \Longrightarrow H_S z_S \neq 0zS​=0⟹HS​zS​=0.

It is left to show that ∀c∈Fp2k\forall c \in \mathbb{F}_p^{2k}∀c∈Fp2k​, c≠0→HSTc≠0c \neq 0 \rightarrow H_S^T c \neq 0c=0→HST​c=0. Define the polynomial in Fp\mathbb{F}_pFp​

f(x)=c2kx2k−1+c2k−1x2k−1+...+c1. f(x) = c_{2k} x^{2k - 1} + c_{2k - 1} x^{2k - 1} + ... + c_1. f(x)=c2k​x2k−1+c2k−1​x2k−1+...+c1​.

Then HSTc=(f(ai))i∈[S]H_S^T c = ( f(a_i ) )_{i \in [S] }HST​c=(f(ai​))i∈[S]​. As f(x)f(x)f(x) has at most 2k−12k - 12k−1 distinct roots, and the (ai)i∈[S](a_i)_{i \in [S] }(ai​)i∈[S]​ are different, there exists some i∈[S]i \in [S]i∈[S] such that f(ai)≠0f(a_i) \neq 0f(ai​)=0.

Decode

Given y=Enc(x)=Hxy = \mathbb{Enc}(x) = H xy=Enc(x)=Hx, how can we recover xxx? We can loop over every subset S⊂[n]S \subset [n ]S⊂[n] of size 2k2k2k and compute x′=HS−1yx' = H_S^{-1} yx′=HS−1​y. If x′x'x′ is kkk sparse, by the property of HHH, it is the unique kkk-sparse vector such that HSx′=yH_S x' = yHS​x′=y.

Remark: The proposed method is exponential respect to kkk. However, there is an algorithm (called syndrome decoding) to perform the recovery in O(k2poly(log⁡p))O(k^2 poly(\log p))O(k2poly(logp)) time.

Space and Time

Space. The algorithm uses O(klog⁡(nM))O(k \log (nM))O(klog(nM)) bits.

This is because we don’t store HHH. For the finite field Fp\mathbb{F}_pFp​, there exists at least one primitive element whose powers give all nonzero elements. We can pick such a primitive element aaa, and set a1=aa_1 = aa1​=a, a2=a2a_2 = a^2a2​=a2, …, an=ana_n = a^nan​=an. Storing y=Hxy = Hxy=Hx requires only O(klog⁡(nM))O(k \log (nM))O(klog(nM)) bits.

Time. Processing each update (i,Δ)(i, \Delta)(i,Δ) in the stream takes O(k)O(k)O(k) time.

Solution 2

We first show how to recover an 111 sparse vector when negative updates are allowed, then use it as a black box to recover kkk sparse vector.

1 sparse recovery

We show an algorithm that successes with probability n/pn / pn/p.

First, we pick a non-zero integer zzz uniformly at random from Fp\mathbb{F}_pFp​. Let

H=[111...1123...nzz2z3...zn]. H = \begin{bmatrix} 1 &1 &1 &... &1 \\ 1 &2 &3 &... &n \\ z &z^2 &z^3 &... &z^n \end{bmatrix}. H=⎣⎢⎡​11z​12z2​13z3​.........​1nzn​⎦⎥⎤​.

The algorithm consists of 3 parts.

Initialize:
\qquad w←{0}3w \leftarrow \{ 0 \}^3w←{0}3
\qquad Sample zzz uniformly from 1,...,p−11, ..., p - 11,...,p−1.

Updates: (i,Δ)(i, \Delta)(i,Δ)
\qquad w←w+Δ⋅Hiw \leftarrow w + \Delta \cdot H_iw←w+Δ⋅Hi​, where HiH_iHi​ is the iiith column of HHH.

Output:
\qquad If w1=0w_1 = 0w1​=0 or w3≠w1⋅zw2/w1w_3 \neq w_1 \cdot z^{w_2 / w_1}w3​=w1​⋅zw2​/w1​:
\qquad\qquad Return xxx is not 111 sparse;
\qquad Else:
\qquad\qquad Return j≐w2/w1j \doteq w_2 / w_1j≐w2​/w1​

Failure Analysis

Theorem. The algorithm fails with probability n/pn / pn/p.

Observe that

w1=∑i∈[n]xi,w2=∑i∈[n]i⋅xi,w3=∑i∈[n]zi⋅xi. w_1 = \sum_{i \in [n] } x_i, \qquad w_2 = \sum_{i \in [n] } i \cdot x_i, \qquad w_3 = \sum_{i \in [n] } z^i \cdot x_i. w1​=i∈[n]∑​xi​,w2​=i∈[n]∑​i⋅xi​,w3​=i∈[n]∑​zi⋅xi​.

If w1=0w_1 = 0w1​=0, either x=0x = 0x=0 or there is cancellation. Conditioned on w1≠0w_1 \neq 0w1​=0, if xxx is 111 sparse, then

w1=xj,w2=j⋅xj,w3=zj⋅xj. w_1 = x_j, \qquad w_2 = j \cdot x_j, \qquad w_3 = z^j \cdot x_j. w1​=xj​,w2​=j⋅xj​,w3​=zj⋅xj​.

Hence, j=w2/w1j = w_2 / w_1j=w2​/w1​ is exactly the non-zero index, and w3=w1⋅zjw_3 = w_1 \cdot z^{j}w3​=w1​⋅zj.

If xxx is not 111 sparse, then

w3−w1⋅zj w_3 - w_1 \cdot z^{j} w3​−w1​⋅zj

is a polynomial of degree at most nnn. It has at most nnn distinct roots with one of them being 000. The probability that zzz being a root is at most (n−1)/(p−1)≤n/p(n - 1) / (p - 1) \le n / p(n−1)/(p−1)≤n/p.

Space and Time

Space. The algorithm uses O(log⁡(nM))O(\log (nM))O(log(nM)) bits.

Time. Processing each update (i,Δ)(i, \Delta)(i,Δ) takes O(1)O(1)O(1) time.

kkk sparse recovery

To apply the 111 sparse recovery data structure, we partition xxx into 2k2k2k subsets randomly. In particular, we use a pairwise hash function that maps each i∈[n]i \in [n]i∈[n] to [2k][2k][2k] uniformly at random. For ℓ∈[2k]\ell \in [2k]ℓ∈[2k], let SℓS_\ellSℓ​ be the set of indices mapped to ℓ\ellℓ:

Sℓ≐{i∈[n]:h(i)=ℓ}. S_\ell \doteq \{ i \in [n]: h(i) = \ell \}. Sℓ​≐{i∈[n]:h(i)=ℓ}.

Then we run 111 sparse recovery on each partition. If some partition contains only one nonzero index, then we recover it successfully.

Theorem. If xxx is kkk sparse, an nonzero dimension iii is recovered with probability 1/21 / 21/2.

Proof. It suffices to prove that iii is the only nonzero index in Sh(i)S_{h (i) }Sh(i)​. For j∈supp(x)j \in \text{supp}(x)j∈supp(x), define the indicator variable XjX_jXj​ which equals 111 if h(j)=h(i)h(j) = h(i)h(j)=h(i) and equals 0 otherwise. By Markov’s inequality and linearity of expectation,

Pr⁡[∑i≠j∈supp(x)Xj≥1]≤E[∑i≠j∈supp(x)Xj]=∑i≠j∈supp(x)E[Xj]≤k−12k≤12. \Pr\left[ \sum_{ i \neq j \in \text{supp}(x) } X_j \ge 1 \right] \le \mathbb{E} \left[ \sum_{ i \neq j \in \text{supp}(x) } X_j \right] = \sum_{ i \neq j \in \text{supp}(x) } \mathbb{E} \left[ X_j \right] \le \frac{k - 1}{2k} \le \frac{1}{2}. Pr⎣⎢⎡​i=j∈supp(x)∑​Xj​≥1⎦⎥⎤​≤E⎣⎢⎡​i=j∈supp(x)∑​Xj​⎦⎥⎤​=i=j∈supp(x)∑​E[Xj​]≤2kk−1​≤21​.

Remark. The Markov’s inequality is rather tight here. Even if we have a fully independent hash function hhh, the probability that none of the nonzero indices collides with iii is given by

(1−12k)k−1⪅exp⁡(−k−12k)≈exp⁡(−12)≈0.60653. \left( 1 - \frac{1}{2k} \right)^{k - 1} \lessapprox \exp \left( - \frac{k - 1}{2k} \right) \approx \exp \left( - \frac{1}{2} \right) \approx 0.60653. (1−2k1​)k−1⪅exp(−2kk−1​)≈exp(−21​)≈0.60653.

□\square□

Corollary. Running log⁡(k/δ)\log (k / \delta)log(k/δ) independent copies of the above structure reduce the failure probability to δ\deltaδ.

Space and Time

Space. The algorithm uses O(k(log⁡(k/δ))log⁡(nM))O(k (\log (k / \delta)) \log (nM))O(k(log(k/δ))log(nM)) bits.

Time. Processing each update (i,Δ)(i, \Delta)(i,Δ) takes O(log⁡(k/δ))O(\log (k / \delta))O(log(k/δ)) time.

Norm of Random Variables

Posted on 2021-03-27 Edited on 2024-03-11

Fix probability space (Ω,F,Pr⁡)(\Omega, \mathcal{F}, \Pr)(Ω,F,Pr), for real number p>0p > 0p>0, let LpL_pLp​ denote the vector space of real value random variable for which E∣X∣p<∞\mathbb{E} |X|^p < \inftyE∣X∣p<∞.

For p≥1p \ge 1p≥1, the ppp norm ∥X∥p\Vert X \Vert_p∥X∥p​ of a random variable X∈LpX \in L_pX∈Lp​ is defined as

∥X∥p=(E[∣X∣p])1/p. \Vert X \Vert_p = \left( \mathbb{E} \big[ |X|^p \big] \right)^{1 / p}. ∥X∥p​=(E[∣X∣p])1/p.

Norm

∥X∥p\Vert X \Vert_p∥X∥p​ is a norm.

Proof. This can be proven directly by Minkowski’s inequality. For completeness, we give the details here. Let X,Y∈LpX, Y \in L_pX,Y∈Lp​, and let a=∥X∥pa = \Vert X \Vert_pa=∥X∥p​ and b=∥Y∥pb = \Vert Y \Vert_pb=∥Y∥p​. We want to prove that

∥X+Y∥p≤a+b⟺∥aa+b⋅Xa+aa+b⋅Ya∥p≤1. \Vert X + Y \Vert_p \le a + b \Longleftrightarrow \left\Vert \frac{a}{ a + b} \cdot \frac{X}{a} + \frac{a}{ a + b} \cdot \frac{Y}{a} \right\Vert_p \le 1. ∥X+Y∥p​≤a+b⟺∥∥∥∥∥​a+ba​⋅aX​+a+ba​⋅aY​∥∥∥∥∥​p​≤1.

It suffices to assume that ∥X∥p=∥Y∥p=1\Vert X \Vert_p = \Vert Y \Vert_p = 1∥X∥p​=∥Y∥p​=1 and prove that

For t∈[0,1]t \in [0, 1]t∈[0,1], ∥tX+(1−t)Y∥p≤1\Vert t X + (1 - t) Y \Vert_p \le 1∥tX+(1−t)Y∥p​≤1.

This is much easier to prove as we can take the power of ppp of both side and show that:

∥tX+(1−t)Y∥pp=E[∣tX+(1−t)Y∣p]≤E[∣tX∣p+∣(1−t)Y∣p]=E[∣tX∣p]+E[∣(1−t)Y∣p]=tp∥X∥pp+(1−t)p∥Y∥pp≤t+(1−t)=1. \begin{aligned} \Vert t X + (1 - t) Y \Vert_p^p &= \mathbb{E}[ |t X + (1 - t) Y |^p ] \\ &\le \mathbb{E}[ | tX |^p + | (1 - t) Y|^p ] \\ &= \mathbb{E}[ | tX |^p ] + \mathbb{E} [ | ( 1 - t) Y|^p ] \\ &= t^p \Vert X \Vert_p^p + ( 1 - t)^p \Vert Y \Vert_p^p \\ &\le t + (1 - t) \\ &= 1. \end{aligned} ∥tX+(1−t)Y∥pp​​=E[∣tX+(1−t)Y∣p]≤E[∣tX∣p+∣(1−t)Y∣p]=E[∣tX∣p]+E[∣(1−t)Y∣p]=tp∥X∥pp​+(1−t)p∥Y∥pp​≤t+(1−t)=1.​

□\square□

Properties

Theorem. For 0≤p≤q0 \le p \le q0≤p≤q, (E[∣X∣p])1/p≤(E[∣X∣q])1/q\big( \mathbb{E} [ |X|^p ] \big)^{1 / p} \le \big( \mathbb{E} [ |X|^q ] \big)^{1 / q}(E[∣X∣p])1/p≤(E[∣X∣q])1/q.

Corollary For 1≤p≤q1 \le p \le q1≤p≤q, ∥X∥p≤∥X∥q\Vert X \Vert_p \le \Vert X \Vert_q∥X∥p​≤∥X∥q​.

Proof. By convexity of the function y=∣x∣q/py = |x|^{q / p}y=∣x∣q/p, we have

∣E[∣X∣p]∣q/p≤E[∣∣X∣p∣q/p]=E[∣X∣q] \begin{aligned} \Big| \mathbb{E} \big[ |X|^p \big] \Big|^{q / p} \le \mathbb{E} \left[ \Big| |X|^p \Big|^{q / p} \right] = \mathbb{E} \left[ |X|^q \right] \end{aligned} ∣∣∣∣​E[∣X∣p]∣∣∣∣​q/p≤E[∣∣∣∣​∣X∣p∣∣∣∣​q/p]=E[∣X∣q]​

Raising both hand sides to the power of 1/q1 / q1/q finish the proof.

□\square□

Let X1,...,Xn∈LpX_1, ..., X_n \in L_pX1​,...,Xn​∈Lp​ be independent random variables and let r1,...,rnr_1, ... ,r_nr1​,...,rn​ be independent Rademacher random variables. Then

∥∑i∈[n]Xi−E[∑i∈[n]Xi]∥p≤2⋅∥∑i∈[n]riXi∥p \left\Vert \sum_{i \in [n] } X_i - \mathbb{E} \left[ \sum_{i \in [n] } X_i \right] \right\Vert_p \le 2 \cdot \left\Vert \sum_{i \in [n] } r_i X_i \right\Vert_p ∥∥∥∥∥∥∥​i∈[n]∑​Xi​−E⎣⎢⎡​i∈[n]∑​Xi​⎦⎥⎤​∥∥∥∥∥∥∥​p​≤2⋅∥∥∥∥∥∥∥​i∈[n]∑​ri​Xi​∥∥∥∥∥∥∥​p​

Proof. For i∈[n]i \in [n]i∈[n], let YiY_iYi​ be independent copy of XiX_iXi​. Then

∥∑i∈[n]Xi−E[∑i∈[n]Xi]∥p=∥∑i∈[n]Xi−EY[∑i∈[n]Yi]∥p=(EX[∣∑i∈[n]Xi−EY[∑i∈[n]Yi]∣p])1/p≤(EXEY[∣∑i∈[n]Xi−∑i∈[n]Yi∣p])1/p(Jensen)=∥∑i∈[n](Xi−Yi)∥p \begin{aligned} \left\Vert \sum_{i \in [n] } X_i - \mathbb{E} \left[ \sum_{i \in [n] } X_i \right] \right\Vert_p &= \left\Vert \sum_{i \in [n] } X_i - \mathbb{E}_Y \left[ \sum_{i \in [n] } Y_i \right] \right\Vert_p \\ &= \left( \mathbb{E}_X \left[ \left| \sum_{i \in [n] } X_i - \mathbb{E}_Y \left[ \sum_{i \in [n] } Y_i \right] \right|^p \right] \right)^{1 / p} \\ &\le \left( \mathbb{E}_X \mathbb{E}_Y \left[ \left| \sum_{i \in [n] } X_i - \sum_{i \in [n] } Y_i \right|^p \right] \right)^{1 / p} &( \text{Jensen}) \\ &= \left\Vert \sum_{i \in [n] } (X_i - Y_i) \right\Vert_p \end{aligned} ∥∥∥∥∥∥∥​i∈[n]∑​Xi​−E⎣⎢⎡​i∈[n]∑​Xi​⎦⎥⎤​∥∥∥∥∥∥∥​p​​=∥∥∥∥∥∥∥​i∈[n]∑​Xi​−EY​⎣⎢⎡​i∈[n]∑​Yi​⎦⎥⎤​∥∥∥∥∥∥∥​p​=⎝⎛​EX​⎣⎢⎡​∣∣∣∣∣∣∣​i∈[n]∑​Xi​−EY​⎣⎢⎡​i∈[n]∑​Yi​⎦⎥⎤​∣∣∣∣∣∣∣​p⎦⎥⎤​⎠⎞​1/p≤⎝⎛​EX​EY​⎣⎢⎡​∣∣∣∣∣∣∣​i∈[n]∑​Xi​−i∈[n]∑​Yi​∣∣∣∣∣∣∣​p⎦⎥⎤​⎠⎞​1/p=∥∥∥∥∥∥∥​i∈[n]∑​(Xi​−Yi​)∥∥∥∥∥∥∥​p​​(Jensen)​

Let Z=(Z1,...,Zn)Z = (Z_1, ..., Z_n)Z=(Z1​,...,Zn​) be a sequence of independent random variables, such that either Zi=Xi−YiZ_i = X_i - Y_iZi​=Xi​−Yi​ or Zi=Yi−XiZ_i = Y_i - X_iZi​=Yi​−Xi​. Let Γ={Z}\Gamma = \{ Z \}Γ={Z} be the set of 2n2^n2n such sequences. As Xi−YiX_i - Y_iXi​−Yi​ and Yi−XiY_i - X_iYi​−Xi​ have the same distributions, we have for Z∈ΓZ \in \GammaZ∈Γ,

EZ[∣∑i∈[n]Zi∣p]=EX,Y[∣∑i∈[n]Xi−Yi∣p]. \mathbb{E}_Z \left[ \left| \sum_{i \in [n] } Z_i \right|^p \right] = \mathbb{E}_{X, Y} \left[ \left| \sum_{i \in [n]} X_i - Y_i \right|^p \right]. EZ​⎣⎢⎡​∣∣∣∣∣∣∣​i∈[n]∑​Zi​∣∣∣∣∣∣∣​p⎦⎥⎤​=EX,Y​⎣⎢⎡​∣∣∣∣∣∣∣​i∈[n]∑​Xi​−Yi​∣∣∣∣∣∣∣​p⎦⎥⎤​.

Therefore,

1∣Γ∣∑Z∈ΓEZ[∣∑i∈[n]Zi∣p]=EX,Y[∣∑i∈[n]Xi−Yi∣p]. \frac{1}{ |\Gamma| } \sum_{ Z \in \Gamma } \mathbb{E}_Z \left[ \left| \sum_{i \in [n] } Z_i \right|^p \right] = \mathbb{E}_{X, Y} \left[ \left| \sum_{i \in [n]} X_i - Y_i \right|^p \right]. ∣Γ∣1​Z∈Γ∑​EZ​⎣⎢⎡​∣∣∣∣∣∣∣​i∈[n]∑​Zi​∣∣∣∣∣∣∣​p⎦⎥⎤​=EX,Y​⎣⎢⎡​∣∣∣∣∣∣∣​i∈[n]∑​Xi​−Yi​∣∣∣∣∣∣∣​p⎦⎥⎤​.

If R=(r1,...,rn)R = (r_1, ..., r_n)R=(r1​,...,rn​) are Rademacher random variables, then (r1(X1−Y1),...,rn(Xn−Yn)(r_1 (X_1 - Y_1), ..., r_n(X_n - Y_n)(r1​(X1​−Y1​),...,rn​(Xn​−Yn​) gives a uniformly sequence in Γ\GammaΓ. It holds that

EREX,Y[∣∑i∈[n]ri(Xi−Yi)∣p]=1∣Γ∣∑Z∈ΓEZ[∣∑i∈[n]Zi∣p]=EX,Y[∣∑i∈[n]Xi−Yi∣p]. \mathbb{E}_R \mathbb{E}_{X, Y} \left[ \left| \sum_{i \in [n]} r_i (X_i - Y_i) \right|^p \right] = \frac{1}{ |\Gamma| } \sum_{ Z \in \Gamma } \mathbb{E}_Z \left[ \left| \sum_{i \in [n] } Z_i \right|^p \right] = \mathbb{E}_{X, Y} \left[ \left| \sum_{i \in [n]} X_i - Y_i \right|^p \right]. ER​EX,Y​⎣⎢⎡​∣∣∣∣∣∣∣​i∈[n]∑​ri​(Xi​−Yi​)∣∣∣∣∣∣∣​p⎦⎥⎤​=∣Γ∣1​Z∈Γ∑​EZ​⎣⎢⎡​∣∣∣∣∣∣∣​i∈[n]∑​Zi​∣∣∣∣∣∣∣​p⎦⎥⎤​=EX,Y​⎣⎢⎡​∣∣∣∣∣∣∣​i∈[n]∑​Xi​−Yi​∣∣∣∣∣∣∣​p⎦⎥⎤​.

Hence,

∥∑i∈[n]Xi−E[∑i∈[n]Xi]∥p≤∥∑i∈[n](Xi−Yi)∥p=∥∑i∈[n]ri(Xi−Yi)∥p≤2∥∑i∈[n]riXi∥p \begin{aligned} \left\Vert \sum_{i \in [n] } X_i - \mathbb{E} \left[ \sum_{i \in [n] } X_i \right] \right\Vert_p &\le \left\Vert \sum_{i \in [n] } (X_i - Y_i) \right\Vert_p \\ &= \left\Vert \sum_{i \in [n] } r_i(X_i - Y_i) \right\Vert_p \\ &\le 2 \left\Vert \sum_{i \in [n] } r_i X_i \right\Vert_p \end{aligned} ∥∥∥∥∥∥∥​i∈[n]∑​Xi​−E⎣⎢⎡​i∈[n]∑​Xi​⎦⎥⎤​∥∥∥∥∥∥∥​p​​≤∥∥∥∥∥∥∥​i∈[n]∑​(Xi​−Yi​)∥∥∥∥∥∥∥​p​=∥∥∥∥∥∥∥​i∈[n]∑​ri​(Xi​−Yi​)∥∥∥∥∥∥∥​p​≤2∥∥∥∥∥∥∥​i∈[n]∑​ri​Xi​∥∥∥∥∥∥∥​p​​

□\square□

Remark: We can simply the argument as follows. For a fixed sequence (r1,...,rn)∈{−1,1}n(r_1,..., r_n) \in \{-1, 1 \}^n(r1​,...,rn​)∈{−1,1}n, the sequence (r1(X1−Y1),...,rn(Xn−Yn))(r_1(X_1 - Y_1), ..., r_n(X_n - Y_n) )(r1​(X1​−Y1​),...,rn​(Xn​−Yn​)) has the same distribution as (X1−Yn,...,Xn−Yn)(X_1 - Y_n, ..., X_n - Y_n)(X1​−Yn​,...,Xn​−Yn​). Averaging over all such possible sequences gives that

∥∑i∈[n](Xi−Yi)∥p=∥∑i∈[n]ri(Xi−Yi)∥p. \left\Vert \sum_{i \in [n] } (X_i - Y_i) \right\Vert_p = \left\Vert \sum_{i \in [n] } r_i(X_i - Y_i) \right\Vert_p. ∥∥∥∥∥∥∥​i∈[n]∑​(Xi​−Yi​)∥∥∥∥∥∥∥​p​=∥∥∥∥∥∥∥​i∈[n]∑​ri​(Xi​−Yi​)∥∥∥∥∥∥∥​p​.

Let X1,...,XnX_1, ..., X_nX1​,...,Xn​ be independent and mean zero random variables and let Y1,...,YnY_1, ..., Y_nY1​,...,Yn​ be independent copies of them. Then for any (ai,j)(a_{i, j} )(ai,j​) and for p≥1p \ge 1p≥1, it holds that

∥∑i≠jai,jXiXj∥p≤4∥∑i≠jai,jXiYj∥p \begin{aligned} \left\Vert \sum_{i \neq j} a_{i,j} X_i X_j \right\Vert_p \le 4\left\Vert \sum_{i \neq j} a_{i,j} X_i Y_j \right\Vert_p \end{aligned} ∥∥∥∥∥∥∥​i=j∑​ai,j​Xi​Xj​∥∥∥∥∥∥∥​p​≤4∥∥∥∥∥∥∥​i=j∑​ai,j​Xi​Yj​∥∥∥∥∥∥∥​p​​

Proof. Let B1,...,BnB_1, ..., B_nB1​,...,Bn​ be independent Bernoulli random variables each of expectation 1/21 / 21/2. Then

∥∑i≠jai,jXiXj∥p=(EX[∣∑i≠jai,jXiXj∣p])1/p=(EX[∣4EB[∑i≠jai,jXiXjBi(1−Bj)]∣p])1/p≤(EX[EB[4∣∑i≠jai,jXiXjBi(1−Bj)∣p]])1/p(Jensen)=4(EXEB[∣∑i≠jai,jXiXjBi(1−Bj)∣p])1/p=4(EBEX[∣∑i≠jai,jXiXjBi(1−Bj)∣p])1/p \begin{aligned} \left\Vert \sum_{i \neq j} a_{i,j} X_i X_j \right\Vert_p &= \left( \mathbb{E}_X \left[ \left| \sum_{i \neq j} a_{i,j} X_i X_j \right|^p \right]\right)^{1 / p} \\ &= \left( \mathbb{E}_X \left[ \left| 4 \mathbb{E}_B \left[ \sum_{i \neq j} a_{i,j} X_i X_j B_i (1 - B_j) \right] \right|^p \right]\right)^{1 / p} \\ &\le \left( \mathbb{E}_X \left[ \mathbb{E}_B \left[ 4 \left| \sum_{i \neq j} a_{i,j} X_i X_j B_i (1 - B_j) \right|^p \right] \right]\right)^{1 / p} & (\text{Jensen} ) \\ &= 4 \left( \mathbb{E}_X \mathbb{E}_B \left[ \left| \sum_{i \neq j} a_{i,j} X_i X_j B_i (1 - B_j) \right|^p \right]\right)^{1 / p} \\ &= 4 \left( \mathbb{E}_B \mathbb{E}_X \left[ \left| \sum_{i \neq j} a_{i,j} X_i X_j B_i (1 - B_j) \right|^p \right]\right)^{1 / p} \end{aligned} ∥∥∥∥∥∥∥​i=j∑​ai,j​Xi​Xj​∥∥∥∥∥∥∥​p​​=⎝⎛​EX​⎣⎢⎡​∣∣∣∣∣∣∣​i=j∑​ai,j​Xi​Xj​∣∣∣∣∣∣∣​p⎦⎥⎤​⎠⎞​1/p=⎝⎛​EX​⎣⎢⎡​∣∣∣∣∣∣∣​4EB​⎣⎢⎡​i=j∑​ai,j​Xi​Xj​Bi​(1−Bj​)⎦⎥⎤​∣∣∣∣∣∣∣​p⎦⎥⎤​⎠⎞​1/p≤⎝⎛​EX​⎣⎢⎡​EB​⎣⎢⎡​4∣∣∣∣∣∣∣​i=j∑​ai,j​Xi​Xj​Bi​(1−Bj​)∣∣∣∣∣∣∣​p⎦⎥⎤​⎦⎥⎤​⎠⎞​1/p=4⎝⎛​EX​EB​⎣⎢⎡​∣∣∣∣∣∣∣​i=j∑​ai,j​Xi​Xj​Bi​(1−Bj​)∣∣∣∣∣∣∣​p⎦⎥⎤​⎠⎞​1/p=4⎝⎛​EB​EX​⎣⎢⎡​∣∣∣∣∣∣∣​i=j∑​ai,j​Xi​Xj​Bi​(1−Bj​)∣∣∣∣∣∣∣​p⎦⎥⎤​⎠⎞​1/p​(Jensen)​

Question to ponder: Under what condition can we exchange the order of expectation (integration)?

But

EBEX[∣∑i≠jai,jXiXjBi(1−Bj)∣p]≤max⁡BEX[∣∑i≠jai,jXiXjBi(1−Bj)∣p]. \mathbb{E}_B \mathbb{E}_X \left[ \left| \sum_{i \neq j} a_{i,j} X_i X_j B_i (1 - B_j) \right|^p \right] \le \max_B \mathbb{E}_X \left[ \left| \sum_{i \neq j} a_{i,j} X_i X_j B_i (1 - B_j) \right|^p \right]. EB​EX​⎣⎢⎡​∣∣∣∣∣∣∣​i=j∑​ai,j​Xi​Xj​Bi​(1−Bj​)∣∣∣∣∣∣∣​p⎦⎥⎤​≤Bmax​EX​⎣⎢⎡​∣∣∣∣∣∣∣​i=j∑​ai,j​Xi​Xj​Bi​(1−Bj​)∣∣∣∣∣∣∣​p⎦⎥⎤​.

Let

B∗=(b1∗,...,bn∗)=arg⁡max⁡BEX[∣∑i≠jai,jXiXjBi(1−Bj)∣p] B^* = (b^*_1, ..., b^*_n) = \arg \max_{B} \mathbb{E}_X \left[ \left| \sum_{i \neq j} a_{i,j} X_i X_j B_i (1 - B_j) \right|^p \right] B∗=(b1∗​,...,bn∗​)=argBmax​EX​⎣⎢⎡​∣∣∣∣∣∣∣​i=j∑​ai,j​Xi​Xj​Bi​(1−Bj​)∣∣∣∣∣∣∣​p⎦⎥⎤​

Define S≐{i:bi∗=1}S \doteq \{ i : b^*_i = 1 \}S≐{i:bi∗​=1}. Then

EX[∣∑i≠jai,jXiXjbi∗(1−bj∗)∣p]=EX[∣∑i∈S,j∉Sai,jXiXj∣p]=EX,Y[∣∑i∈S,j∉Sai,jXiYj∣p]\begin{aligned} \mathbb{E}_X \left[ \left| \sum_{i \neq j} a_{i,j} X_i X_j b^*_i (1 - b^*_j) \right|^p \right] &= \mathbb{E}_X \left[ \left| \sum_{i \in S, j \notin S } a_{i,j} X_i X_j \right|^p \right] \\ &= \mathbb{E}_{X, Y} \left[ \left| \sum_{i \in S, j \notin S } a_{i,j} X_i Y_j \right|^p \right] \end{aligned} EX​⎣⎢⎡​∣∣∣∣∣∣∣​i=j∑​ai,j​Xi​Xj​bi∗​(1−bj∗​)∣∣∣∣∣∣∣​p⎦⎥⎤​​=EX​⎣⎢⎡​∣∣∣∣∣∣∣​i∈S,j∈/S∑​ai,j​Xi​Xj​∣∣∣∣∣∣∣​p⎦⎥⎤​=EX,Y​⎣⎢⎡​∣∣∣∣∣∣∣​i∈S,j∈/S∑​ai,j​Xi​Yj​∣∣∣∣∣∣∣​p⎦⎥⎤​​

Let Z1,...,ZnZ_1, ..., Z_nZ1​,...,Zn​ and Z1′,...,Zn′Z_1', ..., Z_n'Z1′​,...,Zn′​ both be independent copies of X1,...,XnX_1, ..., X_nX1​,...,Xn​. Then

EX,Y[∣∑i∈S,j∉Sai,jXiYj∣p]=EX,Y[∣EZ,Z′(∑i∈Sai,jXi⋅(∑j∉SYj+∑j∈SZj′)+∑i∉Sai,jZi⋅(∑j∉SYj+∑j∈SZj′))∣p](E[Zi]=E[Zj′]=0)≤EX,YEZ,Z′[∣∑i∈Sai,jXi⋅(∑j∉SYj+∑j∈SZj′)+∑i∉Sai,jZi⋅(∑j∉SYj+∑j∈SZj′)∣p](Jensen)=EX,Y[∣∑i,jai,jXiYj∣p].\begin{aligned} \mathbb{E}_{X, Y} \left[ \left| \sum_{i \in S, j \notin S } a_{i,j} X_i Y_j \right|^p \right] &= \mathbb{E}_{X, Y} \left[ \left| \mathbb{E}_{Z, Z'} \left( \sum_{i \in S} a_{i,j} X_i \cdot \left( \sum_{j \notin S} Y_j + \sum_{j \in S} Z_j' \right) + \sum_{i \notin S} a_{i,j} Z_i \cdot \left( \sum_{j \notin S} Y_j + \sum_{j \in S} Z_j' \right) \right) \right|^p \right] & ( \mathbb{E}[Z_i ] = \mathbb{E} [ Z_j' ] = 0 ) \\ &\le \mathbb{E}_{X, Y} \mathbb{E}_{Z, Z'} \left[ \left| \sum_{i \in S} a_{i,j} X_i \cdot \left( \sum_{j \notin S} Y_j + \sum_{j \in S} Z_j' \right) + \sum_{i \notin S} a_{i,j} Z_i \cdot \left( \sum_{j \notin S} Y_j + \sum_{j \in S} Z_j' \right) \right|^p \right] & (\text{Jensen} ) \\ &=\mathbb{E}_{X, Y} \left[ \left| \sum_{i , j } a_{i,j} X_i Y_j \right|^p \right]. \end{aligned} EX,Y​⎣⎢⎡​∣∣∣∣∣∣∣​i∈S,j∈/S∑​ai,j​Xi​Yj​∣∣∣∣∣∣∣​p⎦⎥⎤​​=EX,Y​⎣⎢⎡​∣∣∣∣∣∣∣​EZ,Z′​⎝⎛​i∈S∑​ai,j​Xi​⋅⎝⎛​j∈/S∑​Yj​+j∈S∑​Zj′​⎠⎞​+i∈/S∑​ai,j​Zi​⋅⎝⎛​j∈/S∑​Yj​+j∈S∑​Zj′​⎠⎞​⎠⎞​∣∣∣∣∣∣∣​p⎦⎥⎤​≤EX,Y​EZ,Z′​⎣⎢⎡​∣∣∣∣∣∣∣​i∈S∑​ai,j​Xi​⋅⎝⎛​j∈/S∑​Yj​+j∈S∑​Zj′​⎠⎞​+i∈/S∑​ai,j​Zi​⋅⎝⎛​j∈/S∑​Yj​+j∈S∑​Zj′​⎠⎞​∣∣∣∣∣∣∣​p⎦⎥⎤​=EX,Y​[∣∣∣∣∣∣​i,j∑​ai,j​Xi​Yj​∣∣∣∣∣∣​p].​(E[Zi​]=E[Zj′​]=0)(Jensen)​

□\square□

Fast Fourier Transform In Finite Field

Posted on 2021-03-24

We discuss the fast Fourier transform in a finite field F\mathbb{F}F with size ppp.

For w∈Fw \in \mathbb{F}w∈F, and n∈F+n \in \mathbb{F}_+n∈F+​, define

Mw,n≐[1ww2...wn−11w2w4...w2(n−1)...1wnw2n...wn(n−1)]. M_{w, n} \doteq \begin{bmatrix} 1 &w &w^2 &... &w^{n - 1} \\ 1 &w^2 &w^4 &... &w^{2(n - 1)} \\ ... \\ 1 &w^{n} &w^{2n} &... &w^{n(n - 1)} \end{bmatrix}. Mw,n​≐⎣⎢⎢⎢⎡​11...1​ww2wn​w2w4w2n​.........​wn−1w2(n−1)wn(n−1)​⎦⎥⎥⎥⎤​.

If the following two conditions hold:

  1. nnn is some power of 222 and;
  2. wn=1w^n = 1wn=1 in the finite field.

Then ∀x⃗≐(x1,x2,...,xn)∈Fn\forall \vec x \doteq (x_1, x_2, ..., x_n) \in \mathbb{F}^n∀x≐(x1​,x2​,...,xn​)∈Fn, we can compute

Mw,nx⃗=[1ww2...wn−11w2w4...w2(n−1)...1wnw2n...wn(n−1)][x1x2...xn] M_{w, n} \vec x = \begin{bmatrix} 1 &w &w^2 &... &w^{n - 1} \\ 1 &w^2 &w^4 &... &w^{2(n - 1)} \\ ... \\ 1 &w^{n} &w^{2n} &... &w^{n(n - 1)} \end{bmatrix} \begin{bmatrix} x_1 \\ x_2 \\ ... \\ x_n \end{bmatrix} Mw,n​x=⎣⎢⎢⎢⎡​11...1​ww2wn​w2w4w2n​.........​wn−1w2(n−1)wn(n−1)​⎦⎥⎥⎥⎤​⎣⎢⎢⎢⎡​x1​x2​...xn​​⎦⎥⎥⎥⎤​

in O(nlog⁡n)O(n \log n)O(nlogn) time.

Proof. If n=2n = 2n=2, then the claim holds trivially.

Otherwise, let d=n/2=2k−1d = n / 2 = 2^{k - 1}d=n/2=2k−1 and v=w2v = w^2v=w2. The odd columns of the first ddd rows of the matrix Mw,nM_{w, n}Mw,n​ constitutes

[1w2w4...wn−21w4w8...w2(n−2)...1w2dw4d...wd(n−2)]=[1vv2...vd−11v2v4...v2(d−1)...1vdv2d...vd(d−1)]=Mv,d. \begin{bmatrix} 1 &w^2 &w^4 &... &w^{n - 2} \\ 1 &w^4 &w^8 &... &w^{2(n - 2)} \\ & & &... \\ 1 &w^{2d} &w^{4d} &... &w^{d(n - 2)} \end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix} 1 &v &v^2 &... &v^{d - 1} \\ 1 &v^2 &v^4 &... &v^{2(d - 1)} \\ & & &... \\ 1 &v^{d} &v^{2d} &... &v^{d(d - 1)} \end{bmatrix} = M_{v, d}. ⎣⎢⎢⎢⎡​111​w2w4w2d​w4w8w4d​............​wn−2w2(n−2)wd(n−2)​⎦⎥⎥⎥⎤​=⎣⎢⎢⎢⎡​111​vv2vd​v2v4v2d​............​vd−1v2(d−1)vd(d−1)​⎦⎥⎥⎥⎤​=Mv,d​.

By assumption, for even numbers i=2,4,...,(n−2)i = 2, 4, ..., (n - 2)i=2,4,...,(n−2), we have i⋅d=1i \cdot d = 1i⋅d=1 in the finite field. Hence, the odd columns of the last ddd rows of Mw,nM_{w, n}Mw,n​ is

[1w2(d+1)w4(d+1)...w(n−2)(d+1)1w2(d+2)w4(d+2)...w(n−2)(d+2)...1w2(d+d)w4(d+d)...w(n−2)(d+d)]=[1w2w4...wn−21w4w8...w2(n−2)...1w2dw4d...wd(n−2)]=Mv,d. \begin{bmatrix} 1 &w^{2(d + 1)} &w^{4(d + 1)} &... &w^{(n - 2)(d + 1)} \\ 1 &w^{2(d + 2)} &w^{4(d + 2)} &... &w^{(n - 2)(d + 2)} \\ & & &... \\ 1 &w^{2(d + d)} &w^{4(d + d)} &... &w^{(n - 2)(d + d)} \end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix} 1 &w^2 &w^4 &... &w^{n - 2} \\ 1 &w^4 &w^8 &... &w^{2(n - 2)} \\ & & &... \\ 1 &w^{2d} &w^{4d} &... &w^{d(n - 2)} \end{bmatrix} = M_{v, d}. ⎣⎢⎢⎢⎡​111​w2(d+1)w2(d+2)w2(d+d)​w4(d+1)w4(d+2)w4(d+d)​............​w(n−2)(d+1)w(n−2)(d+2)w(n−2)(d+d)​⎦⎥⎥⎥⎤​=⎣⎢⎢⎢⎡​111​w2w4w2d​w4w8w4d​............​wn−2w2(n−2)wd(n−2)​⎦⎥⎥⎥⎤​=Mv,d​.

Let x⃗o,x⃗e∈Fd\vec x_o, \vec x_e \in \mathbb{F}^dxo​,xe​∈Fd be the vectors obtained by the odd and even dimensions of x⃗\vec xx respectively. By our construction,

  1. ddd is some power of 222 and;
  2. vd=wn=1v^d = w^n = 1vd=wn=1.

Hence, by induction hypothesis we can compute Mv,dx⃗oM_{v, d} \vec x_oMv,d​xo​ in O(dlog⁡d)=O(nlog⁡n)O(d \log d) = O( n \log n)O(dlogd)=O(nlogn) time.

Next, consider the even columns of the first ddd rows of the matrix Mw,nM_{w, n}Mw,n​ constitutes

[ww3w5...wn−1w2w6w10...w2(n−1)...wdw3dw5d...wd(n−1)]=[w...w2......wd][1w2w4...wn−21w4w8...w2(n−2)...1w2dw4d...wd(n−2)]=[w...w2......wd]Mv,d\begin{aligned} \begin{bmatrix} w &w^3 &w^5 &... &w^{n - 1} \\ w^2 &w^6 &w^{10} &... &w^{2(n - 1)} \\ & & &... \\ w^d &w^{3d} &w^{5d} &... &w^{d(n - 1)} \end{bmatrix} &= \begin{bmatrix} w &... & \\ &w^2 &... \\ & & &... \\ & & & & w^d \\ \end{bmatrix} \begin{bmatrix} 1 &w^2 &w^4 &... &w^{n - 2} \\ 1 &w^4 &w^8 &... &w^{2(n - 2)} \\ & & &... \\ 1 &w^{2d} &w^{4d} &... &w^{d(n - 2)} \end{bmatrix} \\ &= \begin{bmatrix} w &... & \\ &w^2 &... \\ & & &... \\ & & & & w^d \\ \end{bmatrix} M_{v, d} \end{aligned} ⎣⎢⎢⎢⎡​ww2wd​w3w6w3d​w5w10w5d​............​wn−1w2(n−1)wd(n−1)​⎦⎥⎥⎥⎤​​=⎣⎢⎢⎢⎡​w​...w2​...​...​wd​⎦⎥⎥⎥⎤​⎣⎢⎢⎢⎡​111​w2w4w2d​w4w8w4d​............​wn−2w2(n−2)wd(n−2)​⎦⎥⎥⎥⎤​=⎣⎢⎢⎢⎡​w​...w2​...​...​wd​⎦⎥⎥⎥⎤​Mv,d​​

Similarly, the even columns of the last ddd rows of the matrix Mw,nM_{w, n}Mw,n​ constitutes

[wd+1...wd+2......wd+d]Mv,d=(−1)[w...w2......wd]Mv,d.\begin{aligned} \begin{bmatrix} w^{d + 1} &... & \\ &w^{d + 2} &... \\ & & &... \\ & & & & w^{d + d} \\ \end{bmatrix} M_{v, d} = (-1) \begin{bmatrix} w &... & \\ &w^2 &... \\ & & &... \\ & & & & w^d \\ \end{bmatrix} M_{v, d}. \end{aligned} ⎣⎢⎢⎢⎡​wd+1​...wd+2​...​...​wd+d​⎦⎥⎥⎥⎤​Mv,d​=(−1)⎣⎢⎢⎢⎡​w​...w2​...​...​wd​⎦⎥⎥⎥⎤​Mv,d​.​

The equality comes from that wd=wn/2=−1w^d = w^{n / 2} = -1wd=wn/2=−1. By induction hypothesis, we can compute Mv,dx⃗eM_{v, d} \vec x_eMv,d​xe​ in O(nlog⁡n)O(n \log n)O(nlogn) time.

Finally, the first ddd dimensions of Mw,nx⃗M_{w, n} \vec xMw,n​x equals

Mv,dx⃗o+[w...w2......wd]Mv,dx⃗e, M_{v, d} \vec x_o + \begin{bmatrix} w &... & \\ &w^2 &... \\ & & &... \\ & & & & w^d \\ \end{bmatrix} M_{v, d} \vec x_e, Mv,d​xo​+⎣⎢⎢⎢⎡​w​...w2​...​...​wd​⎦⎥⎥⎥⎤​Mv,d​xe​,

which can be computed in O(nlog⁡n)+O(nlog⁡n)+O(n)=O(nlog⁡n)O(n \log n) + O(n \log n) + O(n) = O(n \log n)O(nlogn)+O(nlogn)+O(n)=O(nlogn) time.

The last ddd dimensions of Mw,nx⃗M_{w, n} \vec xMw,n​x equals

Mv,dx⃗o−[w...w2......wd]Mv,dx⃗e, M_{v, d} \vec x_o - \begin{bmatrix} w &... & \\ &w^2 &... \\ & & &... \\ & & & & w^d \\ \end{bmatrix} M_{v, d} \vec x_e, Mv,d​xo​−⎣⎢⎢⎢⎡​w​...w2​...​...​wd​⎦⎥⎥⎥⎤​Mv,d​xe​,

which can also be computed in O(nlog⁡n)+O(nlog⁡n)+O(n)=O(nlog⁡n)O(n \log n) + O(n \log n) + O(n) = O(n \log n)O(nlogn)+O(nlogn)+O(n)=O(nlogn) time.

□\square□
